exciton–phonon coupling may lead to a wider PL peak, which
is undesirable for monochromatic LEDs. However, in some
other applications, strong exciton–phonon coupling is desir­
able and may be beneficial for the white light emission
broadband short­pulse lasers. The biexciton binding energy of
is found to be 60 meV and that of (C
is 44 meV. They are relatively larger values compared to other
semiconductors. This is so because the value of biexciton
binding energy depends on the gap energy difference between
“well” and “barrier” in the quantum well structure.
Sanvitto’s group reported that biexciton also influenced exciton
confinement and spectral response, in terms of affecting the
cations cause different bandgap energies and lead to different
Yan et al. reported that replacing MA with FA in
the bandgap of the 2D perovskites, but also improved
film is only 1.51 eV, which is much smaller
a good PCE of 6.88%. Quarti et al. proved that the electronic
properties of the 2D perovskites were influenced by the length
of the organic alkyl chain, and a longer chain led to an increase
indicates that this effect is caused by
octahedral structure due to the long
alkyl chains. So, the size of organic cations plays an important
role in adjusting the inorganic layer structure, thus leading to
the length of the alkyl chain between the aromatic
ring and the ammonium group, rather than the number of aro­
matic rings, is vital in the bandgap of 2D perovskites containing
aromatic cations (Figure 5c). In addition to the chain length
and dielectric constant of cations discussed earlier, perovskite
phase transition can also affect the structure and optical proper­
ties. Through in situ high­pressure XRD, the shift of exciton
